Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: User-Centered System for Improved Coordination across the Continuum of Care
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project focuses on using analytics and technology to benefit patients who require additional care to fully recover - or simply to maintain their health - after being discharged from the hospital. Whether subacute or community-based care, significant opportunity exists to leverage machine learning, decision science, and advance data mining techniques to better support patients. State and federal budgets cover the costs of care for millions of Americans every year. This expenditure is growing faster than inflation, prompting the development of both optional and mandatory payment reform efforts that stand to simultaneously reduce costs and improve care outcomes. If successful, this project will help reduce costs of care for healthcare providers, payers, and government/society.

The proposed project aims to incorporate and improve upon user-centered decision science in healthcare. The proposed platform will combine advanced machine learning techniques with a patient/family-centered business model. The innovation will harness multiple streams of healthcare data, such as claims/billing data from acute, subacute, and community care settings. If successful, this research will impact the state-of-the-art in healthcare analytics and outcomes measurement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
State and federal budgets cover the costs of care for millions of Americans every year. This expenditure is growing faster than inflation, prompting the development of both optional and mandatory payment reform efforts that stand to simultaneously reduce costs and improve care outcomes. This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project focused on using advanced analytics to benefit patients who require additional care to fully recover from illness - or simply to maintain their health over time. This project leveraged machine learning, decision science, and advanced data mining techniques to better support such patients.

 

The project focused on socioeconomically disadvantaged and disabled patients. These demographics often suffer from poor health outcomes and such patients are known to be a driver of substantial cost and inefficiency within the healthcare system. Prior research has identified a high prevalence of chronic conditions, high rates of avoidable hospital readmissions, and an inadequate focus on social determinants of health by care providers.

 

The outcome of this project was a novel software platform to help identify patients with clinical and social risk factors that put them at risk for poor outcomes and high cost. The system automatically generates lists of high quality resources and care providers. It then matches individual patients with the resources they need, based on critical clinical and social risk factors.

 

The generalizable impact of this work lies in the ability to elevate social risk factors, to specify which aspects drive poor outcomes for an individual patient, and to suggest post-acute or community-based providers who have a track record of success with similar patients.

 


Last Modified: 06/04/2021
Modified by: Thaddeus R Fulford-Jones

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project focused on using advanced analytics to benefit patients who require additional care to fully recover from illness - or simply to maintain their health over time. This project leveraged machine learning, decision science, and advanced data mining techniques to better support such patients. The project focused on socioeconomically disadvantaged and disabled patients. These demographics often suffer from poor health outcomes and such patients are known to be a driver of substantial cost and inefficiency within the healthcare system. Prior research has identified a high prevalence of chronic conditions, high rates of avoidable hospital readmissions, and an inadequate focus on social determinants of health by care providers. The outcome of this project was a novel software platform to help identify patients with clinical and social risk factors that put them at risk for poor outcomes and high cost. The system automatically generates lists of high quality resources and care providers. It then matches individual patients with the resources they need, based on critical clinical and social risk factors. The generalizable impact of this work lies in the ability to elevate social risk factors, to specify which aspects drive poor outcomes for an individual patient, and to suggest post-acute or community-based providers who have a track record of success with similar patients.
